repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Discussed as an idea in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/28296.

Changes the defaults for `'grepprg'` and `'grepformat'` to use ripgrep and its `--vimgrep` mode, if available on the system.

Points discussed in the thread:

- Zero configuration: This PR provides a better default for an existing vim feature (`:grep`), which the user is free to configure themselves as needed. It adds no additional configuration settings or hooks.
- Low to zero maintenance: The change consists of a single `executable()` check and two option changes. It is very unlikely that ripgrep will experience breaking changes in its CLI that would necessitate adjusting the code or adding version checking.
- Performance: A basic benchmark (running a recursive, fixed string search on the neovim repository) shows significant performance improvements over GNU grep (few seconds vs <1 second).
- Precedence: Many popular plugins already integrate with ripgrep for searching, and ripgrep itself provides features specifically for integrating with vim (`--vimgrep` format, `--smart-case` option). This makes it a promising candidate for a place where Neovim can match the pulse of the community.

This is my first PR to adjust core Neovim code, as such there's a few points I am seeking feedback on:

- Is this change wanted? The discussion thread concluded that the change is promising, but may not be wanted by Neovim users.
- Is the documentation appropriate? I Added a small note to the documentation of `'grepprg'` that points the user toward ripgrep and why they may want to use it. Is it clear enough that this default only takes effect if the *user makes sure* that the `rg` binary is found by Neovim?
- Does this need extra testing? @clason mentioned a `:checkhealth` test, I'm unsure what that should look like.

I'm happy to make any necessary adjustments.

comment_data.body: No need to explain what `ripgrep` is -- but the different defaults (`.gitignore`) should be called out (and possibly disabled by default; some people -- myself included -- prefer the `grep` default).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3401,6 +3401,13 @@ return {
         apply equally to 'grepprg'.
         This option cannot be set from a |modeline| or in the |sandbox|, for
         security reasons.
+        If ripgrep is available (|executable()|) then this option and |'grepformat'|
+        default to "rg --vimgrep ..." and "%f:%l:%c:%m" respectively.
+        Ripgrep is a faster, recursive grep that respects gitignore rules
+        and skips hidden and binary files by default, and supports most of the common grep options.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        default to `rg --vimgrep ...` and `%f:%l:%c:%m` respectively.
```

and so on.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3401,6 +3401,13 @@ return {
         apply equally to 'grepprg'.
         This option cannot be set from a |modeline| or in the |sandbox|, for
         security reasons.
+        If ripgrep is available (|executable()|) then this option and |'grepformat'|
+        default to "rg --vimgrep ..." and "%f:%l:%c:%m" respectively.

comment_data.body: I don't think that's correct now (since the default can be `ripgrep`). Maybe just "see below" if it's too much to explain here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3382,7 +3382,7 @@ return {
         condition = 'MSWIN',
         if_false = 'grep -n $* /dev/null',
         if_true = 'findstr /n $* nul',
-        doc = [["grep -n ",
+        doc = [[Windows: "findstr /n $* nul",
            Unix: "grep -n $* /dev/null"]],

comment_data.body: Should be in "Performance" section unless @clason strongly objects
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -383,13 +383,27 @@ local function check_terminal()
   end
 end
 
+local function check_external_tools()
+  health.start('External Tools')

comment_data.body: Not strongly, but I would like to extend this section to other "optional tools" (like `curl`). And that would make a consistent format (path, version) easier to parse.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -383,13 +383,27 @@ local function check_terminal()
   end
 end
 
+local function check_external_tools()
+  health.start('External Tools')

comment_data.body:
I think listing the order of tools in reverse priority is very unintuitive. I think it's better to present it like `:h clipboard-tool` to eliminate any ambiguities. Something like (adjust text as needed):

  - ripgrep
  - findstr (Windows)
  - grep (Unix)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2870,6 +2869,16 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	apply equally to 'grepprg'.
 	This option cannot be set from a |modeline| or in the |sandbox|, for
 	security reasons.
+	This option defaults to `findstr /n $* nul` on Windows
+	and `grep -n $* /dev/null` elsewhere.
+	Additionally, if ripgrep is available (|executable()|) then this option
+	and |'grepformat'| default to `rg --vimgrep -uuu ...` and `%f:%l:%c:%m` respectively.

comment_data.body: some structure in the text would also be helpful.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2870,6 +2869,16 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	apply equally to 'grepprg'.
 	This option cannot be set from a |modeline| or in the |sandbox|, for
 	security reasons.
+	This option defaults to `findstr /n $* nul` on Windows
+	and `grep -n $* /dev/null` elsewhere.
+	Additionally, if ripgrep is available (|executable()|) then this option
+	and |'grepformat'| default to `rg --vimgrep -uuu ...` and `%f:%l:%c:%m` respectively.

comment_data.body: Follow-up: the location of the used `rg` would be _really_ useful (`vim.fn.exepath()`) to debug `$PATH` issues.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -383,13 +383,27 @@ local function check_terminal()
   end
 end
 
+local function check_external_tools()
+  health.start('External Tools')
+
+  if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+    local rg = vim.fn.exepath('rg')
+    local cmd = 'rg -V'
+    local out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+    health.ok(('%s (%s)'):format(vim.trim(out), rg))

@@ -486,3 +486,11 @@ if tty then
     end
   end
 end
+
+--- Default grepprg to ripgrep if available.

comment_data.body:
single-quotes automatically link options, so bars are redundant.
```suggestion
        If ripgrep ('grepprg') is available, this option defaults to "%f:%l:%c:%m".
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3368,6 +3368,8 @@ return {
         Format to recognize for the ":grep" command output.
         This is a scanf-like string that uses the same format as the
         'errorformat' option: see |errorformat|.
+
+        If ripgrep (|'grepprg'|) is available, this option defaults to `%f:%l:%c:%m`.

@@ -3368,6 +3368,8 @@ return {
         Format to recognize for the ":grep" command output.
         This is a scanf-like string that uses the same format as the
         'errorformat' option: see |errorformat|.
+
+        If ripgrep (|'grepprg'|) is available, this option defaults to `%f:%l:%c:%m`.

comment_data.body:
It's already being printed? it prints `ripgrep 14.1.0 (/usr/bin/rg)` on my system.

or are you saying the value of `grepprg` should use the exepath too?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -383,13 +383,27 @@ local function check_terminal()
   end
 end
 
+local function check_external_tools()
+  health.start('External Tools')
+
+  if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+    local rg = vim.fn.exepath('rg')
+    local cmd = 'rg -V'
+    local out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+    health.ok(('%s (%s)'):format(vim.trim(out), rg))

comment_data.body: That's fine, then! (Sorry, should have tested before commenting.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -383,13 +383,27 @@ local function check_terminal()
   end
 end
 
+local function check_external_tools()
+  health.start('External Tools')
+
+  if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+    local rg = vim.fn.exepath('rg')
+    local cmd = 'rg -V'
+    local out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+    health.ok(('%s (%s)'):format(vim.trim(out), rg))

comment_data.body: Nit: in _this_ case I would move this line to after the `'shortmess'` entry (to keep treesitter stuff at the end).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -377,6 +377,7 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for treesitter query files.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for help files.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for Lua files.
+   'grepprg' defaults to using ripgrep if available.

@@ -377,6 +377,7 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for treesitter query files.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for help files.
    Enabled treesitter highlighting for Lua files.
+   'grepprg' defaults to using ripgrep if available.

comment_data.body:
Apologies for the late review, but what is the rationale for `-uuu` rather than `-uu`? Is this strictly for compatibility with `grep` (which also searches binary files by default)?

Omitting binary file matches strikes me as a better default for a text editor. If the concern is consistent behavior for both `rg` and `grep`, I'd suggest adding `-I` to the default `grepprg` to ignore binary file matches in all cases.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -486,3 +486,11 @@ if tty then
     end
   end
 end
+
+--- Default 'grepprg' to ripgrep if available.
+if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+  -- Match :grep default, otherwise rg searches cwd by default
+  -- Use -uuu to make ripgrep not do its default filtering
+  vim.o.grepprg = 'rg --vimgrep -uuu $* ' .. (vim.fn.has('unix') == 1 and '/dev/null' or 'nul')

comment_data.body: yes rg -uuu matches grep -r. I do agree that omitting binary files would be better. The documentation at least points out that the user may wish to adjust the flags used
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -486,3 +486,11 @@ if tty then
     end
   end
 end
+
+--- Default 'grepprg' to ripgrep if available.
+if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+  -- Match :grep default, otherwise rg searches cwd by default
+  -- Use -uuu to make ripgrep not do its default filtering
+  vim.o.grepprg = 'rg --vimgrep -uuu $* ' .. (vim.fn.has('unix') == 1 and '/dev/null' or 'nul')

comment_data.body:
The use of `/dev/null` here is also unnecessary AFAIK. It's used for grep because some versions of grep (e.g. BSD grep) will try to read from stdin if no file argument is given, so a plain `grep foo` will block indefinitely and the `/dev/null` argument prevents that.

But ripgrep does not behave that way, and adding `/dev/null` here means you cannot use `:grep foo` to search for foo recursively (since that expands to `rg -uuu foo /dev/null`, which of course returns nothing).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -486,3 +486,11 @@ if tty then
     end
   end
 end
+
+--- Default 'grepprg' to ripgrep if available.
+if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+  -- Match :grep default, otherwise rg searches cwd by default
+  -- Use -uuu to make ripgrep not do its default filtering
+  vim.o.grepprg = 'rg --vimgrep -uuu $* ' .. (vim.fn.has('unix') == 1 and '/dev/null' or 'nul')

comment_data.body: ripgrep searches the current directory by default. given it's also recursive by default, the /dev/null placeholder is to be both consistent with regular grep, and to prevent an accidental grep without files from potentially spinning up a lengthy process.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -486,3 +486,11 @@ if tty then
     end
   end
 end
+
+--- Default 'grepprg' to ripgrep if available.
+if vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1 then
+  -- Match :grep default, otherwise rg searches cwd by default
+  -- Use -uuu to make ripgrep not do its default filtering
+  vim.o.grepprg = 'rg --vimgrep -uuu $* ' .. (vim.fn.has('unix') == 1 and '/dev/null' or 'nul')

comment_regular_data.body:
> a :checkhealth test, I'm unsure what that should look like.

I would recommend a new section on "optional tools" that checks `vim.fn.executable('rg') == 1` and prints `OK` if so and `WARN` if not. Bonus points for adding 
* `which rg` and
* `rg --version` 

output. (We can extend this later with `curl` and `git` and `tree-sitter`, once we use them.)
Have adjusted the documentation, turned off the default filtering (with a note in the documentation hinting the user they may want to re-enable it if they wish), and added a rudimentary healthcheck.
I have overhauled the documentation as requested. I've kept the health check in the proposed 'External Tools' section for now.

> Needs a `news.txt` (and probably also `vim-diff.txt`) entry.

For vim-diff, which section? `nvim-defaults`? Is a single line calling out `grepprg` sufficient?

For news.txt, is this `news-breaking` or `news-changed` (or `news-features`, even) ? Is there a specific ordering to those sections or should it simply go at the end?

> For vim-diff, which section? `nvim-defaults`? Is a single line calling out `grepprg` sufficient?

I'd say `nvim-defaults`

> For news.txt, is this `news-breaking` or `news-changed` (or `news-features`, even) ? Is there a specific ordering to those sections or should it simply go at the end?

I'd say to the "Defaults:" list under `news-changed` (at the end).
Added. For the sake of brevity I did not include the full default value, since both places link to the option where it's documented.
Happy to have landed this! Thank you for the feedback and advice.
Thanks for this! The PR description and the context is useful, be sure to add that to the commit message as well next time :)

Given the feedback by @gpanders, is it worthwhile to revisit this before 0.10? Either when https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23235 is closer to completion, or I could do it this weekend. The change is still very young, so I don't think many people have seen or given feedback on it yet, but I do think the suggestions are worth considering.
Sure, can still be changed (but also in a 0.10.x, so not a blocker either way).

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: issues or PRs involving changing the defaults
labels.name: defaults

title: feat(defaults): use ripgrep (rg) for 'grepprg' if available
